text:
394, 396, 398 Hudson Street, east side, between West Houston (formerly Hammersley) and Clarkson Streets.
About 1920.
Gift of E.M. Jenks.

387-403 Hudson Street Building, newly erected for the Western Electric Company, west side, from West Houston (formerly Hammersley) Street to Clarkson Street.

June 15, 1921.

Gift of E. M. Jenks.

Hudson Street at West Houston (formerly Hammersley) Street, the N. W. corner seen from and including the cleared S. E. corner. part of the excavation for the new United States Appraisers 51 Stores Building, which fills the entire block from Varick Street to Hudson.

December 7, 1927.

P. L. Sperr.

(1)
Public School No. 95, 250-260 West Houston Street, north side, between Varick and Hudson Streets, seen from the cleared block on the south side, where the new United States Appraisers Stores Building is to be erected.

December 7, 1927.

P. L. Sperr.

(2)
The same from a different view on Hudson St.East between Houston and Leroy Streets, showing Public School #95.

May 20th, 1940.

P.L.Sperr,

(1)
Public School No. 95, 250-260 West Houston Street, north side, between Varick and Hudson Streets, seen from the cleared block on the south side, where the new United States Appraisers Stores Building is to be erected.

December 7, 1927.

P. L. Sperr.

(2)
The same from a different view on Hudson St.East between Houston and Leroy Streets, showing Public School #95.

May 20th, 1940.

P.L.Sperr,

262 West Houston Street, north side, east of Hudson Street, adjoining Public School No. 95. This is a shack less than eight years old, as shown.

June 15, 1930.

P. L. Sperr.

(1)
301, 297 to 281 West Houston Street, south side, west of, adjoining, and at Hudson Street, including the row of old houses with dormer windows which used to be 102 to 92 Hammersley Street, before 1858, when that street was absorbed by Houston Street, losing its own name.
July 16, 1932.

P. L. Sperr.

(2)
Rear view of 293 to 281 West Houston Street, two years earlier. At the right may be seen the rear of 371 Hudson Street, a four-story tenement house in the middle of a block of much older buildings.
April 23, 1930.

P. L. Sperr.

297 West Houston Street (formerly 102 Hammersley Street), one of a group of seven old houses with dormer windows on the south side of West Houston Street, west of Hudson Street. In the background is shown the King Street side of the new Standard Statistics Building, Hudson Street from Charlton to King Streets. July 16, 1932.

P. L. Sperr.

237 Year Old Land Gift of English Crown Sold to Builder
The site of this row of houses was part of the extensive farm in Greenwich Village which was given to Trinity Church by the British King in 1698. Trinity sold the property recently to Vivian Green, will erect a commercial structure on the block, which is the east side of Hudson Street from West Houston to Clarkson Street.
William S. Sussman was the broker.

Jan. 6, 1935

Manhattan

Hudson Street--Nos. 388-402

Hudson Street,east side,looking northwards across the clearing from West Houston Street.

P.L.Sperr,

September 24th,1938

HUDSON ST. from West Houston St.

395 Hudson Street, west side, north from W. Houston (left) to Clarkson (right) Streets, as viewed northwestward across a clearance on the east side of Hudson Street. This loft building bears the street address as a name and is the property of the New York Central Railroad and forms a portion of their vast holdings in this vicinity. It was completed in June 1921. To the left margin is Houston Street Station of the Ninth Avenue "El" which runs north and southward on Greenwich Street at this point.

September 4, 1938.

P.L. Sperr

(2)

395 Hudson Street, west side, Clarkson to Houston.

P. L. Sperr

September 24, 1938.

395 Hudson Street, west side, north from W. Houston (left) to Clarkson (right) Streets, as viewed northwestward across a clearance on the east side of Hudson Street. This loft building bears the street address as a name and is the property of the New York Central Railroad and forms a portion of their vast holdings in this vicinity. It was completed in June 1921. To the left margin is Houston Street Station of the Ninth Avenue "El" which runs north and southward on Greenwich Street at this point.

September 4, 1938.

P.L. Sperr

395 Hudson Street, west side, Clarkson to Houston.
